causes: The Teutonic Order imposed high taxes and restricted trade, angering Prussian merchants and nobles.
The Prussian Confederation rebelled against the Order’s rule and sought aid from Poland.
Poland, ruled by King Casimir IV Jagiellon, saw an opportunity to expand its influence over Prussia.
events_leading_up_to_war: The Prussian Confederation formally requested Polish protection in 1454.
King Casimir IV declared war on the Teutonic Order and invaded Prussia.
The war turned into a long and costly conflict with shifting battlefronts.

result.general: Polish victory; Teutonic Order forced to accept Polish overlordship.
result.territorial_changes: Western Prussia (Royal Prussia) became part of Poland, while Eastern Prussia remained under Teutonic control as a Polish vassal.

Prussian_Confederation_and_Poland.troops: Over 30,000, including Polish knights and urban militias

Teutonic_Order.troops: Around 25,000, mostly professional knights and mercenaries

Prussian_Confederation_and_Poland.long_term_effect: Cities devastated but gained independence from the Order.

Teutonic_Order.tactical_failure: Mass desertions and loss of major fortresses

major_battles.name: Battle of Chojnice
major_battles.description: Polish forces suffered a devastating defeat due to the superior Teutonic cavalry.

major_battles.name: Siege of Malbork
major_battles.description: Polish forces failed to capture the Teutonic capital but weakened its defenses.

major_battles.name: Battle of Świecino
major_battles.description: Polish forces crushed a Teutonic army, turning the tide of the war.

texts.name: Chronicles of Jan Długosz
texts.details: A detailed record of the war, including battles and diplomatic negotiations.

texts.name: Teutonic Order War Reports
texts.details: Correspondence between Teutonic commanders detailing battlefield conditions.

archaeological_evidence.description: Damage from Polish bombardment still visible.
Recovered Teutonic Order swords and cannon fragments.

political: The Teutonic Order lost much of its power and became a Polish vassal.
Royal Prussia became an autonomous province under Polish rule.
The war marked the rise of Poland as a dominant force in the Baltic.
long_term_effects: Teutonic Order never fully recovered and would later secularize into the Duchy of Prussia (1525).
Gdańsk and other cities gained economic prosperity under Polish rule.
Weakened the influence of knightly orders in Europe, signaling the decline of medieval crusader states.

military: Marked the increasing use of mercenaries in European conflicts.
Demonstrated the decline of knightly orders against centralized state armies.
political: Shifted power in the Baltic from the Teutonic Order to Poland.
Laid the groundwork for future Polish-Lithuanian dominance in Eastern Europe.
cultural: The war led to significant architectural developments in Prussian cities.
Inspired later conflicts over Prussian independence.
